commit_message:
DiskFile refactoring to per-policy classes

Refactors diskfile.py to implement policy-type-specific
diskfile behavior in diskfile (sub-)classes.

This patch creates policy type specific diskfile
classes to allow some inheritance and overriding
of get_ondisk_files and hash_cleanup_listdir.

Also moves the file name mangling methods
from storage_policy.py to diskfile.py (ts_to_fname
and fname_to_ts). IMHO that is the right place for them
since they are diskfile-implementation choices and the new
classes added provide a better home for them.

Change-Id: I303e8551de98301c0fcb154a5ba392034046d72a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/49/162249/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class ReplicationDiskFileHelper(object): def __init__(self, policy): self.policy = policy def is_obsolete(self, filename, other_filename): """ Test if a given file is considered to be obsolete with respect to another file in an object storage dir. The default behavior is to simply compare the two filenames. However, a policy may override this method to implement a different policy-specific behavior. :param filename: a string representing an absolute filename :param other_filename: a string representing an absolute filename :returns: True if filename is considered obsolete and should therefore be deleted; False otherwise. """ return filename < other_filename def _gather_on_disk_file(self, filename, ext, accepted_files, **kwargs): """ Called by diskfile.get_ondisk_files() for each file in an object datadir in reverse sorted order. This method should accept on disk files by adding them to the accepted files dict. Subclasses may override this method to implement policy-specific behavior. When the search is deemed complete, and True is returned, the gathered files will satisfy one of two conditions: * ts_file is not None and data_file is None and meta_file is None and durable_file is None object is considered deleted * (data_file is not None or durable_file is not None) and ts_file is None object exists, and optionally has fast-POST metadata :param filename: name of file to be accepted or not :param ext: extension part of filename :param accepted_files: dict of files that have been previously accepted by a call to this method, keyed by filename extension. :returns: True if all wanted files have been found, False otherwise """ if ext == '.ts': accepted_files['.meta'] = None done = True else: done = (ext == '.data') # gather the first of each file extension accepted_files.setdefault(ext, filename) return done def _verify_on_disk_files(self, accepted_files, **kwargs): """ Verify that the final combination of on disk files complies with the diskfle contract. :param accepted_files: files that have been found and accepted :returns: True if the file combination is compliant, False otherwise """ data_file, meta_file, ts_file = tuple( [accepted_files.get(ext) for ext in ('.data', '.meta', '.ts')]) return ((data_file is None and meta_file is None and ts_file is None) or (ts_file is not None and data_file is None and meta_file is None) or (data_file is not None and ts_file is None)) def get_ondisk_files(self, files, datadir, frag_index=None): """ Given a simple list of files names, determine the files to use. :params files: simple set of files as a python list :params datadir: directory name files are from for convenience :params frag_index: EC may have multiple fragment index data files so if specified this identifies the desired one :returns: a tuple of data, meta, tombstone and durable. """ files.sort(reverse=True) accepted_files = {} for afile in files: ts_file = accepted_files.get('.ts') data_file = accepted_files.get('.data') assert ts_file is None, "On-disk file search loop" \ " continuing after tombstone, %s, encountered" % ts_file assert data_file is None, "On-disk file search loop" \ " continuing after data file, %s, encountered" % data_file ext = splitext(afile)[1] if self._gather_on_disk_file(afile, ext, accepted_files, frag_index=frag_index): assert self._verify_on_disk_files(accepted_files, frag_index=frag_index), \ "On-disk file search algorithm contract is broken: %s" \ % accepted_files.values() result = [(join(datadir, accepted_files.get(ext)) if accepted_files.get(ext) else None) for ext in ('.data', '.meta', '.ts', '.durable')] return tuple(result) def hash_cleanup_listdir(self, hsh_path, reclaim_age=ONE_WEEK): """ List contents of a hash directory and clean up any old files: - For replication policy, delete files older than a .data or .ts file - For EC policy, delete files older than a .durable or .ts file :param hsh_path: object hash path :param reclaim_age: age in seconds at which to remove tombstones :returns: list of files remaining in the directory, reverse sorted """ files = listdir(hsh_path) if len(files) == 1: if files[0].endswith('.ts'): # remove tombstones older than reclaim_age ts = files[0].rsplit('.', 1)[0] if (time.time() - float(Timestamp(ts))) > reclaim_age: remove_file(join(hsh_path, files[0])) files.remove(files[0]) elif files: files.sort(reverse=True) data_file, meta_file, ts_file, durable_file = \ self.get_ondisk_files(files, '') newest_file = durable_file or data_file or ts_file if newest_file: for filename in list(files): if (self.is_obsolete(filename, newest_file) or (meta_file and filename.endswith('.meta') and filename < meta_file)): remove_file(join(hsh_path, filename)) files.remove(filename) return files class ECDiskFileHelper(ReplicationDiskFileHelper): def is_obsolete(self, filename, other_filename): """ Overrides super-class method to implement EC policy specific behavior when comparing files against a .durable file. The default implementation would consider t2#1.data to be older than t2.durable (since t2#1.data < t2.durable). By stripping off the file extensions we get the desired behavior: t2#1 > t2 without compromising the detection of t1#1 < t2. """ if other_filename.endswith('.durable'): return splitext(filename)[0] < splitext(other_filename)[0] return filename < other_filename def _gather_on_disk_file(self, filename, ext, accepted_files, **kwargs): """ In addition to the conditions imposed by the default gather method, for EC policy when the search is deemed complete, and True is returned, the gathered files will satisfy one of two conditions: * data_file is None or durable_file is not None * if data_file then data_file timestamp == durable_file timestamp """ done = False frag_index = kwargs.get('frag_index') if accepted_files.get('.durable'): if ext in ('.durable', '.meta'): # there can no longer be a matching .data file done = True if ext == '.data': if self.is_obsolete(filename, accepted_files.get('.durable')): done = True else: t_data, fi = self.policy.fname_to_ts(filename) if frag_index is None or frag_index == int(fi): done = True accepted_files.setdefault(ext, filename) # else: for EC we keep searching first for a .data file # that matches the specific frag_index requested elif ext == '.data': # ignore .data found before any .durable pass else: # default gather for .ts, .meta and .durable default_gather = super(ECDiskFileHelper, self)._gather_on_disk_file done = default_gather(filename, ext, accepted_files, **kwargs) return done def _verify_on_disk_files(self, accepted_files, **kwargs): frag_index = kwargs.get('frag_index') if frag_index is not None and not accepted_files.get('.data'): # broken, so clear the .meta to comply with superclass assertions. accepted_files['.meta'] = None data_file, meta_file, ts_file, durable_file = tuple( [accepted_files.get(ext) for ext in ('.data', '.meta', '.ts', '.durable')]) return ((data_file is None or durable_file is not None) and (data_file is None and meta_file is None and ts_file is None and durable_file is None) or (ts_file is not None and data_file is None and meta_file is None and durable_file is None) or (data_file is not None and durable_file is not None and ts_file is None) or (durable_file is not None and meta_file is None and ts_file is None)) def get_policy_specific_diskfile(policy): if policy.policy_type == EC_POLICY: return ECDiskFileHelper(policy) return ReplicationDiskFileHelper(policy) def get_ondisk_files(files, datadir, policy, frag_index=None): policy_specific = get_policy_specific_diskfile(policy) return policy_specific.get_ondisk_files(files, datadir, frag_index) policy_specific = get_policy_specific_diskfile( POLICIES.get_by_index(policy_index)) return policy_specific.hash_cleanup_listdir(hsh_path, reclaim_age)
deleted_lines: def get_ondisk_files(files, datadir, policy, frag_index=None): """ Given a simple list of files names, determine the files to use. :params files: simple set of files as a python list :params datadir: directory name files are from for convenience :params policy: a StoragePolicy instance :params frag_index: EC may have multiple fragment index data files so if specified this integer identifies the desired one :returns: a tuple of data, meta, tombstone and durable. The returned tuple will satisfy one of two conditions: * ts_file is not None and data_file is None and meta_file is None and durable_file is None object is considered deleted * (data_file is not None or durable_file is not None) and ts_file is None object exists, and optionally has fast-POST metadata Additionally, for EC policy the returned tuple will satisfy the conditions: * data_file is None or durable_file is not None * if data_file then data_file timestamp == durable_file timestamp """ files.sort(reverse=True) data_file = meta_file = ts_file = durable_file = None for afile in files: assert ts_file is None, "On-disk file search loop" \ " continuing after tombstone, %s, encountered" % ts_file assert data_file is None, "On-disk file search loop" \ " continuing after data file, %s, encountered" % data_file if afile.endswith('.ts'): meta_file = None ts_file = join(datadir, afile) break if afile.endswith('.meta') and not meta_file: if durable_file: # this file must be older than already found durable file, # so matching data file will not be found meta_file = join(datadir, afile) # NOTE: this does not exit this loop, since a fast-POST # operation just updates metadata, writing one or more # .meta files, the data file will have an older timestamp, # so we keep looking. continue if afile.endswith('.data'): if policy.policy_type == EC_POLICY: if not durable_file: continue t_data, fi = policy.fname_to_ts(afile) t_durable = splitext(basename(durable_file))[0] if t_data != t_durable: break if frag_index is not None and frag_index != int(fi): # for EC we keep searching first for a .data file that # matches the specific frag_index requested by the caller continue data_file = join(datadir, afile) break # only care about the first .durable if afile.endswith('.durable'): if durable_file: # this file must be older than already found durable file, # so matching data file will not be found break # continue to look for same timestamp data file durable_file = join(datadir, afile) continue if policy.policy_type == EC_POLICY: if frag_index is not None: # broken, so clear the .meta to comply with following assertions. meta_file = meta_file if data_file else None # EC-specific contract assert (data_file is None or durable_file is not None) # note that the contract does not require use of durable_file assert ((data_file is None and meta_file is None and ts_file is None) or (ts_file is not None and data_file is None and meta_file is None and durable_file is None) or (data_file is not None and ts_file is None) or (durable_file is not None and meta_file is None and ts_file is None)), \ "On-disk file search algorithm contract is broken: data_file:" \ " %s, meta_file: %s, ts_file: %s, durable_file: %s" % \ (data_file, meta_file, ts_file, durable_file) return data_file, meta_file, ts_file, durable_file """ List contents of a hash directory and clean up any old files: - For replication policy, delete files older than a .data or .ts file - For EC policy, delete files older than a .durable or .ts file :param hsh_path: object hash path :param policy_index: the policy index :param reclaim_age: age in seconds at which to remove tombstones :returns: list of files remaining in the directory, reverse sorted """ policy = POLICIES.get_by_index(policy_index) files = listdir(hsh_path) if len(files) == 1: if files[0].endswith('.ts'): # remove tombstones older than reclaim_age ts = files[0].rsplit('.', 1)[0] if (time.time() - float(Timestamp(ts))) > reclaim_age: remove_file(join(hsh_path, files[0])) files.remove(files[0]) elif files: files.sort(reverse=True) data_file, meta_file, ts_file, durable_file = \ get_ondisk_files(files, '', policy) newest_file = durable_file or data_file or ts_file if newest_file: for filename in list(files): if (policy.is_obsolete(filename, newest_file) or (meta_file and filename.endswith('.meta') and filename < meta_file)): remove_file(join(hsh_path, filename)) files.remove(filename) return files

subject: Don't use execute_tasks for pre_provision tasks
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-23 16:02:46.000000000', 'files': ['lib/astute/orchestrator.rb'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-astute/commit/631f96d5a09cc48bfbddcbf056b946c8a80438f0', 'message': 'Don't use execute_tasks for pre_provision tasks

The `execute_tasks` method was designed to execute some abstract tasks
sent by Nailgun. Hence, in the end of execution if all is ok it sends
the "ready" status back to Nailgun. It's wrong in case of pre_provision
tasks, because they don't mean provisioning is done.

Since this commit we're running pre_provision tasks by means Nailgun
Hooks and therefore do not report "ready" when they are done.

Closes-Bug: #1433060
Change-Id: I9d0cf11b1788c85937b5a15e44fc904cb24efbe3
'}]
commit_message:
Don't use execute_tasks for pre_provision tasks

The `execute_tasks` method was designed to execute some abstract tasks
sent by Nailgun. Hence, in the end of execution if all is ok it sends
the "ready" status back to Nailgun. It's wrong in case of pre_provision
tasks, because they don't mean provisioning is done.

Since this commit we're running pre_provision tasks by means Nailgun
Hooks and therefore do not report "ready" when they are done.

Closes-Bug: #1433060
Change-Id: I9d0cf11b1788c85937b5a15e44fc904cb24efbe3

commit_message:
Disable -dibtest jobs

The -dibtest jobs are experimental jobs against devstack-gate to test
dib images for trusty and precise as we bring those images up in new
regions. We are not currently able to bring those images up in rackspace
and we need to free up some disk space on the nodepool server so we are
cleaning up those images. To prevent zuul from getting cranky we also
remove the jobs that use these images from zuul.

Change-Id: I91f8d91318752e09a15d64c8b3c506cf83badca2

commit_message:
Improve developer docs around docker-compose and docker-dev

docker-compose master now requires 1.18 API, which is only available
in the development version of docker.  Show how to retrieve and run it.

Change-Id: Ia3a7a659c495547fcc04d31cf38ffeaaf6fd729a

commit_message:
Bump cryptography version to latest

The newer version of cryptography includes convenience functions
to serialize RSA keys which is useful for keystone and potentially
other projects.

Keystone Fernet tokens (one of the most requested features
for keystone) do not work until 0.7. 

Required for Id18fe9f8488204e73d063d7771357eced82e441f

Change-Id: I98941cce82d3c33bcc95ecc48ecff413ef81664a

commit_message:
re-add pacemaker configuration system (pcs)

The python-pcs package is the packet construction set [1]. This package
has been shipped with Debian/Ubuntu for quite a long time. For some
reason the pacemaker/corosync configuration system [2] has been packaged
for Ubuntu under the name `python-pcs'. Use the correct name (that is,
`pcs', like its RPM counterpart) to resolve the collision.

[1] https://github.com/gvnn3/PCS
[2] https://github.com/feist/pcs


blueprint support-ubuntu-trusty

Change-Id: I7291aff00de3a69add5a2ce1b4edff3bd33c1ba8
Signed-off-by: Sergii Golovatiuk <sgolovatiuk@mirantis.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/11/164111/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: pcs
deleted_lines: python-pcs

commit_message:
WIP: Move triggers from assembly to plan

The high points:
- Moved trigger_id from assembly to plan in datamodels
- Added an internal method to find assemblies by plan
- Moved trigger_uri generation to plan
- Moved trust_id from assembly to plan in datamodels
- Renamed tools/trigger-assembly.py to trigger-app.py
- Deploy, if successful, should destroy (soon, just shutdown)
  other assemblies

The low points:
- ED WHERE ARE YOUR TESTS MAN NOTHING WORKS
- SERIOUSLY YOU DIDN'T EVEN TOUCH THE TESTS
- shell_nobuild doesn't use deployer, so deployer doesn't
  remove old assemblies
- A lot of code was shamelessly teleported to plan_handler
  from assembly_handler, mostly to reduce the complexity of
  these changes. See how well that worked!
- Yes, plan_handler makes use of an assembly_handler. I'm not
  sure if that's the best way to do it, but it's worked well
  enough for most of my attempts!

Change-Id: Ia48f95f7f9def4b473cd51df80554688ae287fa3

commit_message:
Fix race condition for FakeDatasource

Sometimes tests fail locally because the update_from_datasource()
method is called on FakeDatasource, but that method isn't implemented.

Change-Id: If09c0dd5cb5dcc5562568e031014481f548eb952

commit_message:
Add sanity check for OVSDB native support

This check has specific warnings about the need to install the
python-openvswitch package to use OVSDB native. If an unknown
Exception is thrown when doing a simple get_bridges() call, it will
also fail, logging the exception.

Partially-Implements: blueprint vsctl-to-ovsdb
Change-Id: Ibd2dac02c5a93bb391b620cc27bc46a6cdf6d817
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/94/166294/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def check_ovsdb_native(): cfg.CONF.set_override('ovsdb_interface', 'native', group='OVS') result = checks.ovsdb_native_supported() if not result: LOG.error(_LE('Check for native OVSDB support failed.')) return result BoolOptCallback('ovsdb_native', check_ovsdb_native, help=_('Check ovsdb native interface support')), if cfg.CONF.OVS.ovsdb_interface == 'nataive': cfg.CONF.set_override('ovsdb_native', True)

commit_message:
Add Asymmetric Key Support to KMIPSecretStore

The KMIPSecretStore class does not currently support storing or generating
asymmetric keys. This spec proposes adding asymmetric key support to the
KMIPSecretStore class.

Change-Id: Ic1b604f2b4ccd84b1fda7d7ee4a95259fe573df1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican-specs refs/changes/49/160449/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============================================= Add Asymmetric Key Support to KMIPSecretStore ============================================= The KMIPSecretStore class does not currently support storing or generating asymmetric keys. This spec proposes adding asymmetric key support to the KMIPSecretStore class. Problem Description =================== The KMIPSecretStore class does not currently support storing or generating asymmetric keys. It is expected that many use cases will want to use asymmetric keys. This will allow use cases that require asymmetric keys to use the KMIPSecretStore. Proposed Change =============== All changes will occur within barbican.plugin.kmip_secret_store.py. The biggest change will be to implement the generate_asymmetric_key method. In addition to that change the generate_supports and store_secret_supports methods will need to be updated to return values that indicate asymmetric keys are supported. The methods store_secret and get_secret may likely need small changes to support asymmetric keys. Alternatives ------------ This is really the only approach. This spec is to add asymmetric key support to the KMIPSecretStore. The only real alternative is not to add this support. Data Model Impact ----------------- None REST API Impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications & Audit Impact ---------------------------- The KMIPSecretStore could add audit messages when the keys are generated. I am not sure what the requirements are for auditing within secret stores. Other End User Impact --------------------- This will add more features for the end users that use KMIP for the backend of Barbican. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Nathan Reller (rellerreller) Work Items ---------- 1. Update KMIPSecretStore Update KMIPSecretStore with the changes that are in the proposed changes section. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Add tests for the KMIPSecretStore that validate generating, storing, and retrieving of asymmetric keys. Tests will also be added for the supports methods. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ==========

commit_message:
Document requirement of cryptography>=0.7

Fernet tokens are built on features in cryptography 0.7. This is noted by the
fact we pull in cryptography 0.8 from global requirements, but this commit
adds a documentation warning as well.

Change-Id: I876bddce6a3686cd40587294f6b8362951ad6ff3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/74/166874/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. WARNING:: The Fernet token provider assumes functionality from the `cryptography 0.7 <https://pypi.python.org/pypi/cryptography/0.7>`_ library. Using the Fernet token provider with a lower version of cryptography may result in failures.

commit_message:
keep interface_properties on NIC update

interface_properties should be kept on NIC update when no new values were provided.
Nailgun agent updates data this way.
interface_properties should be set to defaults for new interfaces only.

Closes-Bug: #1433486
Change-Id: I7e0ac88dde09f6eb28ed7079b3e3a15689da466e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/66/165366/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_interface_properties_after_update_by_agent(self): meta = self.env.default_metadata() self.env.set_interfaces_in_meta(meta, [ {'name': 'eth0', 'mac': '00:00:00:00:00:00', 'current_speed': 1, 'state': 'up'}]) node = self.env.create_node(api=True, meta=meta) node_data = {'mac': node['mac'], 'meta': meta} # check default interface_properties values resp = self.app.get( reverse('NodeNICsHandler', kwargs={'node_id': node['id']}), headers=self.default_headers) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 200) nic = resp.json_body[0] self.assertEqual(nic['interface_properties'], {'disable_offloading': True, 'mtu': None}) # change mtu nic['interface_properties']['mtu'] = 1500 nodes_list = [{'id': node['id'], 'interfaces': [nic]}] resp_put = self.app.put( reverse('NodeCollectionNICsHandler'), jsonutils.dumps(nodes_list), headers=self.default_headers ) self.assertEqual(resp_put.status_code, 200) # update NICs by agent (no interface_properties values provided) resp = self.app.put( reverse('NodeAgentHandler'), jsonutils.dumps(node_data), headers=self.default_headers) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 200) # check interface_properties values were not reset to default resp = self.app.get( reverse('NodeNICsHandler', kwargs={'node_id': node['id']}), headers=self.default_headers) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 200) resp_nic = resp.json_body[0] self.assertEqual(resp_nic['interface_properties'], {'disable_offloading': True, 'mtu': 1500})

commit_message:
Ensure logrotate's cron scripts exit with logrotate return code

Rewrite comment in logrotate-hourly to prevent possible confusion.

commit_message:
Documentation update

* Split away HTTP API and make sure usage info is enough for users
* Drop release notes for unsupported 0.2
* Various link updates and small fixes
* Forward-port 1.0.1 release notes

Change-Id: Ifa2b306d4a6fff19abc1565dabe7f6609363dc08
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-inspector refs/changes/52/165852/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: HTTP API -------- By default **ironic-discoverd** listens on ``0.0.0.0:5050``, port can be changed in configuration. Protocol is JSON over HTTP. The HTTP API consist of these endpoints: Start Introspection ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ ``POST /v1/introspection/<UUID>`` initiate hardware introspection for node ``<UUID>``. All power management configuration for this node needs to be done prior to calling the endpoint (except when `Setting IPMI Credentials`_). Requires X-Auth-Token header with Keystone token for authentication. Optional parameters: * ``new_ipmi_password`` if set, **ironic-discoverd** will try to set IPMI password on the machine to this value. Power credentials validation will be skipped and manual power on will be required. See `Setting IPMI credentials`_ for details. * ``new_ipmi_username`` provides new IPMI user name in addition to password set by ``new_ipmi_password``. Defaults to current ``ipmi_username`` in node ``driver_info`` field. Response: * 202 - accepted discovery request * 400 - bad request * 401, 403 - missing or invalid authentication * 404 - node cannot be found Get Introspection Status ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ ``GET /v1/introspection/<UUID>`` get hardware discovery status. Requires X-Auth-Token header with Keystone token for authentication. Response: * 200 - OK * 400 - bad request * 401, 403 - missing or invalid authentication * 404 - node cannot be found Response body: JSON dictionary with keys: * ``finished`` (boolean) whether discovery is finished * ``error`` error string or ``null`` Ramdisk Callback ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ ``POST /v1/continue`` internal endpoint for the discovery ramdisk to post back discovered data. Should not be used for anything other than implementing the ramdisk. Request body: JSON dictionary with at least these keys: * ``cpus`` number of CPU * ``cpu_arch`` architecture of the CPU * ``memory_mb`` RAM in MiB * ``local_gb`` hard drive size in GiB * ``interfaces`` dictionary filled with data from all NIC's, keys being interface names, values being dictionaries with keys: * ``mac`` MAC address * ``ip`` IP address * ``boot_interface`` optional MAC address of the NIC that the machine PXE booted from either in standard format ``11:22:33:44:55:66`` or in *PXELinux* ``BOOTIF`` format ``01-11-22-33-44-55-66``. * ``block_devices`` optional block devices information for ``root_device_hint`` plugin, dictionary with keys: * ``serials`` list of serial numbers of block devices. .. note:: This list highly depends on enabled plugins, provided above are expected keys for the default set of plugins. See Plugins_ for details. Response: * 200 - OK * 400 - bad request * 403 - node is not on introspection * 404 - node cannot be found or multiple nodes found Response body: JSON dictionary. If `Setting IPMI Credentials`_ is requested, body will contain the following keys: * ``ipmi_setup_credentials`` boolean ``True`` * ``ipmi_username`` new IPMI user name * ``ipmi_password`` new IPMI password .. _Setting IPMI Credentials: https://github.com/stackforge/ironic-discoverd#setting-ipmi-credentials .. _Plugins: https://github.com/stackforge/ironic-discoverd#plugins

commit_message:
Start using oslo.policy

While my initial intent was to remove the castellan.common.loggging
module, I realised that this was only being used in
castellan.common.policy. So as a consequence I ended up replacing only
that in the code to start using the now incubated oslo library,
oslo.policy.

Change-Id: I84cb1dd01545186d87204de4c9429d5f8796645c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/castellan refs/changes/43/165743/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_policy import policy CONF = cfg.CONF self.policy_enforcer = policy_enforcer or policy.Enforcer(CONF)
deleted_lines: from castellan.openstack.common import policy self.policy_enforcer = policy_enforcer or policy.Enforcer()

commit_message:
Remove anacron, add plymouth to bootstrap

- removed cronie-noanacron: not used
- added plymouth: as network configuration throws warnings without it

Change-Id: Ic5c8dea32b60c9a7ed9ad856858a4839c7a7daa0
Closes-Bug: 1430291

subject: Implement generic update-on-match feature
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-10 00:02:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db/commit/48a4f37289de42458439a7c65a8b180d97589fc1', 'message': 'Implement generic update-on-match feature

This feature provides an update_on_match() function
that is used to UPDATE a row based on a variety
of criteria, and to then return a fully persistent object
state representing the row that was matched.  It
essentially intends to provide an UPDATE that is guaranteed
to have matched a specific row in the presence of potential
race conditions without using any locking, and to then
return a record of that row as if it had been SELECTed.

To handle the SELECT step, several backend-specific
strategies are provided, which are automatically selected
based on the best available.  The lowest strategy
actually performs a full re-SELECT.  On Postgresql, MySQL
and other databases besides SQLite, more atomic strategies
are available.

Change-Id: I059f4ae6e72cfa6681a179314144214639f283ef

This feature provides the query.update_on_match()
and query.update_returning_pk() methods.

query.update_on_match() is used to UPDATE a row based on a variety
of criteria, and to then return a fully persistent object
state representing the row that was matched.  It
essentially intends to provide an UPDATE that is guaranteed
to have matched a specific row in the presence of potential
race conditions without using any locking, and to then
return a record of that row as if it had been SELECTed.

query.update_returning_pk() is a public method that
also serves as part of the implementation of
query.update_on_match(); this method delivers an UPDATE
statement such that the primary key of the single row
matched is returned; if zero or multiple rows are matched,
and error is raised.   To handle this, several backend-specific
strategies are provided, which are automatically selected
based on the best available.  The lowest strategy
performs a re-SELECT, but still assumes there's
a simple unique column to be queried on, as is currently the
use case in Nova (uuid is present).  On Postgresql, MySQL
and other databases besides SQLite and possibly DB2, more
atomic strategies are used.

commit_message:
Implement generic update-on-match feature

This feature provides the query.update_on_match()
and query.update_returning_pk() methods, as well
as the manufacture_persistent_object(),
manufacture_entity_criteria(), and manufacture_criteria()
utility functions.

query.update_on_match() is used to UPDATE a row based on a variety
of criteria, and to then return a fully persistent object
state representing the row that was matched.  It
essentially intends to provide an UPDATE that is guaranteed
to have matched a specific row in the presence of potential
race conditions without using any locking, and to then
return a record of that row as if it had been SELECTed.

query.update_returning_pk() is a public method that
also serves as part of the implementation of
query.update_on_match(); this method delivers an UPDATE
statement such that the primary key of the single row
matched is returned; if zero or multiple rows are matched,
and error is raised.   To handle this, several backend-specific
strategies are provided, which are automatically selected
based on the best available.  The lowest strategy
performs a re-SELECT, but still assumes there's
a simple unique column to be queried on, as is currently the
use case in Nova (uuid is present).  On Postgresql, MySQL
and other databases besides SQLite and possibly DB2, more
atomic strategies are used.

Change-Id: I059f4ae6e72cfa6681a179314144214639f283ef
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db refs/changes/28/146228/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from sqlalchemy.ext import declarative from sqlalchemy import schema from sqlalchemy import types as sqltypes from oslo_db.sqlalchemy import test_base from oslo_db.sqlalchemy import update_match Base = declarative.declarative_base() class MyModel(Base): __tablename__ = 'my_table' id = schema.Column(sqltypes.Integer, primary_key=True) x = schema.Column(sqltypes.Integer) y = schema.Column(sqltypes.String(40)) z = schema.Column(sqltypes.String(40)) class UpdateMatchTest(test_base.DbTestCase): def setUp(self): super(UpdateMatchTest, self).setUp() Base.metadata.create_all(self.engine) self.addCleanup(Base.metadata.drop_all, self.engine) #self.engine.echo = 'debug' self.session = self.sessionmaker(autocommit=False) self.addCleanup(self.session.close) self.session.add_all([ MyModel(id=1, x=5, y='y1', z='z1'), MyModel(id=2, x=6, y='y1', z='z2'), MyModel(id=3, x=7, y='y1', z='z1'), MyModel(id=4, x=8, y='y2', z='z2'), ]) self.session.commit() def test_update_basic(self): specimen = MyModel( y='y1', z='z2' ) result = update_match.update_on_match( self.session, specimen, values={'x': 9, 'z': 'z3'}, ) self.assertIs(result, specimen) self.assertIn(result, self.session) self.assertEqual(result.id, 2) self.assertEqual(result.z, 'z3') # TODO (zzzeek): many more tests :) class PGUpdateMatchTest( UpdateMatchTest, test_base.PostgreSQLOpportunisticTestCase): pass class MySQLUpdateMatchTest( UpdateMatchTest, test_base.MySQLOpportunisticTestCase): pass

commit_message:
Update default filesystems ignored by disk check

There are several filesystem times that it makes sense to ignore.
Update the default ignore list to include these.

Change-Id: I031fff5f2cd2b4b62dfec0f5e1e5c86df4c76f52

Combine Backend and PoolBackend

As all backends must be PoolBackends, we combine the two classes and
removed the now dead code.

commit_message:
Add CRUD for networks

Add CRUD implementation for networks using the ovn-nbctl utility.
Long term we should use ovsdb directly, but this seems like a
reasonable first cut to get something working quickly.

Change-Id: I1daf88a2227b4f2bf4e23d233d869362cd171deb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/15/166815/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_config import cfg import neutron.agent.linux.utils as linux_utilsovn_opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('database', help=_('location of the ovn-nb database')), ] cfg.CONF.register_opts(ovn_opts, 'ovn') This driver currently executes the ovn-nbctl utility. This works as an initial pass to make something work, but the driver will need to be reworked to use ovsdb directly. @staticmethod def _nbctl_opts(): if cfg.CONF.ovn.database: return '-d %s' % cfg.CONF.ovn.database return '' def _set_network_name(self, network): linux_utils.execute( 'ovn-nbctl %s lswitch-set-external-id %s ' 'neutron:network_name %s' % (self._nbctl_opts(), network['id'], network['name']), run_as_root=True) def create_network_postcommit(self, context): network = context.current() # Create a logical switch with a name equal to the Neutron network # UUID. This provides an easy way to refer to the logical switch # without having to track what UUID OVN assigned to it. linux_utils.execute('ovn-nbctl %s lswitch-add %s' % ( self._nbctl_opts(), network['id']), run_as_root=True) # Go ahead and also set the Neutron ID as an external:id, as that's # where we want to store it long term. linux_utils.execute( 'ovn-nbctl %s lswitch-set-external-id %s neutron:network_id %s' % (self._nbctl_opts(), network['id'], network['id']), run_as_root=True) self._set_network_name(network) network = context.current() # The only field that might get updated that we care about right now is # the name. self._set_network_name(network) network = context.current() linux_utils.execute('ovn-nbctl %s lswitch-del %s' % ( self._nbctl_opts(), network['id']), run_as_root=True)
deleted_lines: def create_network_postcommit(self, context): pass pass pass

commit_message:
Pass $ceilometer to openstack::glance and openstack::controller

Commit I00db51ceb4121e73bfe7e256b895e4fae122a496 added possibility to
control whether Ceilometer notifications are sent, but didn't add
appropriate parameter to higher level classes, making notifications
disabled even if Ceilometer is enabled.

Additionally backport I3f2c29adbfb605ef288962f72ba81c11811cb357 to
glance module.

Change-Id: I2db7c13cd9c59e29e42e5000961eeedc6717e1ee
Closes-Bug: 1433075
Related-Bug: 1425982

commit_message:
Attempt to see what happens with close-fds patch

Update oslo incubator code to the close-fd patch
code to see what impact this has on cinder and to
see if this is a safe (non-breaking) patch to
accept.

Change-Id: Iad420d736932fa166146bc9c60a074c2708f8e76
Depends-On: If5aa626f76dd5068860eef09560a383334fc674c

added_lines: import errno self._socket = self._make_socket(bind_addr) (self.host, self.port) = self._socket.getsockname()[0:2] LOG.info(_LI("%(name)s listening on %(host)s:%(port)s"), {'name': self.name, 'host': self.host, 'port': self.port}) @staticmethod def _make_socket(bind_addr): try: socket = eventlet.listen(bind_addr, family, backlog=backlog) return socket try: dup_socket = self._socket.dup() except EnvironmentError as e: # If the parent closed the process after fork, make sure # we give it our best shot and try to re-open it. if e.errno != errno.EBADF: raise bind_addr = (self.host, self.port) dup_socket = self._socket = self._make_socket(bind_addr)
deleted_lines: try: self._socket = eventlet.listen(bind_addr, family, backlog=backlog) (self.host, self.port) = self._socket.getsockname()[0:2] LOG.info(_LI("%(name)s listening on %(host)s:%(port)s"), {'name': self.name, 'host': self.host, 'port': self.port}) dup_socket = self._socket.dup()

commit_message:
Fixing a bug with files listing when a file was skipped

This fixes a bug where if a file was skipped, it still showed in
the total listing of files, and so it could be associated with the
score of a non-skipped file. To fix these, when a file is skipped
we also remove it from the list of files in scope.

Change-Id: Ifdfe64b5720e1f809385140960b7b2c1d2238a92
Closes-Bug: #1434659
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/bandit refs/changes/12/166812/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # if the user explicitly mentions a file on command line, # we'll scan it, regardless of whether it's in the included # file types list # if we have problems with a file, we'll remove it from the files_list # and add it to the skipped list instead new_files_list = list(self.files_list) new_files_list.remove(fname) # reflect any files which may have been skipped self.files_list = new_files_list :param enforce_glob: Can set to false to bypass extension check
deleted_lines: :param do_enforce_extensions: Can set to false to bypass extension check

commit_message:
Update to distribution-karaf-0.2.3-Helium-SR3

- Use Helium-SR3;
- Minor: Re-arrange dist variables, so the ones to update are close to each other;
- Introduced ODL_URL_PREFIX so opendaylight-ci can provide proxy url prefix

Patch 2: minor: remove non-intended space character
Patch 3: remove extra '/'
Patch 4: even more typos

Change-Id: If753321ea2a59fe00cd8d12a874c459afbf0dc39

commit_message:
Put NTP client config in the end

Put NTP client config in the end of deployment
in order not to break deployment

Change-Id: I84877d1bb4ba8444cb301bdda23cc7fb6eecd49f
Closes-Bug: 1434510

commit_message:
Send notification to controller about HA router state change

The L3 agent gets keepalived state change notifications via
a unix domain socket. These events are now batched and
send out as a single RPC to the server. In case the same
router got updated multiple times during the batch period,
only the latest state is sent.

Partially-Implements: blueprint report-ha-router-master
Change-Id: I36834ad3d9e8a49a702f01acc29c7c38f2d48833

This patch adds signal command checking against action status. We are
not throwing exceptions here because it is not interesting. Instead, we
log an error (as event).

Change-Id: Ifd0b2a2c86729ac44214cd6cab8cf29e651209d2
'}]
commit_message:
Tuned action status checking during signalling

This patch adds signal command checking against action status. We are
not throwing exceptions here because it is not interesting. Instead, we
log an error (as event).

Change-Id: Ifd0b2a2c86729ac44214cd6cab8cf29e651209d2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/56/166756/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from senlin.engine import event as event_mod INIT, WAITING, READY, RUNNING, SUSPENDED, 'INIT', 'WAITING', 'READY', 'RUNNING', 'SUSPENDED', if self.target is None: raise exception.ActionMissingTarget(action=action) '''Send a signal to the action.''' if cmd not in self.COMMANDS: return if cmd == self.CANCEL: expected_statuses = (self.INIT, self.WAITING, self.READY, self.RUNNING) elif cmd == self.SUSPEND: expected_statuses = (self.RUNNING) else: # RESUME expected_statuses = (self.SUSPENDED) if self.status not in expected_statuses: reason = _("Action (%(action)s) is in unexpected status " "(%(actual)s) while expected status should be one of " "(%(expected)s).") % dict(action=self.id, expected=expected_statuses, actual=self.status) event_mod.error(context, self, cmd, status_reason=reason) return
deleted_lines: INIT, WAITING, READY, RUNNING, 'INIT', 'WAITING', 'READY', 'RUNNING', '''Cancel an action execution progress.'''

subject: Properly handle embedded newlines in csv
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-21 13:18:11.000000000', 'files': ['spec/unit/provider/openstack_spec.rb', 'lib/puppet/provider/openstack.rb'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/88614314df64af63b478928376886a2812dc58e0', 'message': "Properly handle embedded newlines in csv

When parsing the response from the OpenStack client values (like
keystone tenant descriptions) can have embedded newline. To avoid this
issue, we drop lines that don't start with a double quoted value until
the first one we find.

(cherry picked from stackforge/puppet-openstacklib,
from commit efa9181201d33a6bcc4dbe0a482a5d213b6fb5fd)
Change-Id: Ie952161b503d2c46637e6a6e1c83b2dfce1c03a7
"}]
commit_message:
Properly handle embedded newlines in csv

When parsing the response from the OpenStack client values (like
keystone tenant descriptions) can have embedded newline. To avoid this
issue, we drop lines that don't start with a double quoted value until
the first one we find.

(cherry picked from stackforge/puppet-openstacklib,
from commit efa9181201d33a6bcc4dbe0a482a5d213b6fb5fd)
Change-Id: Ie952161b503d2c46637e6a6e1c83b2dfce1c03a7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone refs/changes/23/166523/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
response = parse_csv(response) def self.parse_csv(text) # Ignore warnings - assume legitimate output starts with a double quoted # string. Errors will be caught and raised prior to this text = text.split("
").drop_while { |line| line !~ /^".*"/ }.join("
") return CSV.parse(text + "
") end
deleted_lines: # Ignore warnings - assume legitimate output starts with a double quote # Errors will be caught and raised prior to this response = response.split("\n").select { |line| line =~ /^\".*\",\".*\"/ }.join("\n") response = CSV.parse(response.to_s)

commit_message:
Add unit tests for L3, LBaaS, and FWaaS

These items all lacked any UT coverage at all. For now, add very
basic UT coverage to get these working and ensure we catch breakages
in the dependent repositories.

commit_message:
Update L3, LBaaS, and FWaaS code

This updates the code for OpenDaylight L3, LBaaS, and FWaaS. The existing
code wasn't workable due to some basic errors (wrong config values), as
well as needing updating against the latest code in neutron around L3,
LBaaS, and FWaaS.

Change-Id: I70e2e2a215302db0caf98fa1536ec67a5d11dd28

commit_message:
Remove vlan_transparent and mtu for network APIs

For now, remove vlan_transparent and mtu from network create and update
operations we send to ODL. ODL won't expect these to be there.

Change-Id: Idc72a100ffef73da1e886242484cb41afc0e92c8

deleted_lines: odl_utils.try_del(network, ['status', 'subnets']) odl_utils.try_del(network, ['id', 'status', 'subnets', 'tenant_id'])

commit_message:
Correct test_update_port_mac test

Commit [1] and [2] combined to allow the updating of a neutron port's
MAC address. The second commit fixed a bug in the logic for this which
broke the networking-odl unit tests. This commit fixes it by correctly
verifying you cannot update a port's MAC address when using the
networking-odl ML2 MechanismDriver.

[1] cf99eb988e05c56d3842ac388dfe9ada5aa8af86
[2] 89b9e8597816a5ac2f5a48133777c88abb91914e

Change-Id: I9a37dd1f5ef7c43a9b80504fef399c285b01c565

commit_message:
Enable in-process functional test policy to be configured

Currently the in-process tests build a 2 replica, 4 partition,
2 device object ring. This patch allows an alternative policy
and ring to be specified for testing via environment variables
that may optionally be set.

SWIFT_TEST_IN_PROCESS_CONF_DIR - This points the test setup to a
  directory which may have a swift.conf file and ring file. The
  test setup will then prefer these conf files over the samples
  in '/etc'.

SWIFT_TEST_POLICY - This causes the in-process test to
  use the specified policy from the swift.conf file and its
  associated ring for testing (first copying the conf and ring file
  and modifying device parameters to suit in-process testing). If
  not set, the tests will use the default policy.

The in-process tests now start sufficient object servers for the
ring file being tested against.

This should allow in-process functional testing of various policies
and rings (e.g. EC policies) without needing to reconfigure an SAIO
for each test scenario.

The refactoring of the in_process test setup code should also
allow easier addition of other 'hard-coded' test policies/rings
in the future.

Change-Id: I24f5a13de3d296b400da1691dcb53423a9f8a463
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/05/159205/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: When using the 'in-process test' mode, the sample ``proxy-server.conf`` and ``swift.conf`` files are copied from the ``etc/`` directory in the source tree, with some options being modifies to suit in process testing. The source directory for these config files may optionally be specified by setting the environment variable ``SWIFT_TEST_IN_PROCESS_CONF=<custom_conf_source_dir>``. If set, any config file found in ``<custom_conf_source_dir>`` will be preferred over the defaults in ``etc/``. When a ``swift.conf` file is found in ``<custom_conf_source_dir>``, the in-process test mode will be configured to use the policy labelled as``default`` in that file, and if a corresponding ring file is found for that default policy index, it will be copied and used for testing. (The ring file's device parameters are modified to suit in-process testing.) This allows in-process testing to be run against various policy types and ring files.

commit_message:
Set VIF type and details

Set up the proper vif_type and vif_details for OVN.  The VIF will be
plugged into an OVS bridge and we don't want the hybrid ovs + linux
bridge mode used, as OVN will be implementing security group rules in
ovs.

Change-Id: Ib804af12768b5c70fc03e3ca743bb40100a88893
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/14/166814/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.extensions import portbindings self.vif_type = portbindings.VIF_TYPE_OVS # When set to True, Nova plugs the VIF directly into the ovs bridge # instead of using the hybrid mode. self.vif_details = {portbindings.CAP_PORT_FILTER: True}
deleted_lines: pass

commit_message:
Hide new fields via single method

With the introduction of microversions, node fields that are added in
a particular (micro)version should not be made visible to requests
for older versions. This patch puts the logic for handling this for
all such new fields in one method: hide_fields_in_newer_versions().

This should make it easier for developers to know where to add code,
and will (hopefully) prevent multiple methods from popping up for
each new set of fields.

This also removes the exception handling in allow_logical_names()
because it is not needed, since it is no longer being called in a
method where a pecan.request might not be available (eg, when
generating a sample of a Node for the documentation).

Change-Id: Id6aeb3543d447113a8cf702f2e85d8a9ca3858f3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/56/166056/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # if requested version is < 1.3, hide driver_internal_info if pecan.request.version.minor < 3: obj.driver_internal_info = wsme.Unset if not allow_logical_names(): obj.name = wsme.Unset # v1.5 added logical name aliases return pecan.request.version.minor >= 5
deleted_lines: def hide_driver_internal_info(obj): # if requested version is < 1.3, hide driver_internal_info if pecan.request.version.minor < 3: obj.driver_internal_info = wsme.Unset try: # v1.5 added logical name aliases if pecan.request.version.minor < 5: return False # ignore check if we're not in a pecan context except AttributeError: pass return True if not allow_logical_names(): node.name = wsme.Unset hide_driver_internal_info(node)

commit_message:
Fix common misspellings

Wikipedia's list of common misspellings [1] has a machine-readable
version.  This patch fixes those misspellings mentioned in the list
which don't have multiple right variants (as e.g. "accension", which can
be both "accession" and "ascension"), such misspellings are left
untouched.  The list of changes was manually re-checked for false
positives.

[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Lists_of_common_misspellings/For_machines

Change-Id: I52a6f641a203185f9005bc0731d15166ad741161
Signed-off-by: Martin Kletzander <mkletzan@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/65/166765/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Func tests use fedora-heat-test-image

This runs the existing functional tests using the images built in
http://tarballs.openstack.org/heat-test-image/

This image should be a suitable alternative to
Fedora-x86_64-20-20140618-sda, with the extra benefit that it is
prepared to install the heat config agent projects during boot
so that test_server_software_config can be enabled.

This will also allow devstack to no longer load
Fedora-x86_64-20-20140618-sda onto the nodepool images which will reduce
gate resource consumption.

Change-Id: I6041b8d6e7e9422f6e220d7aef0ca38857085e4b

commit_message:
Create tests for patching feature

Add first test for patching environment, which
deploys some cluster and apply patches on it.
Environment configuration (deployment test) is chosen
automatically based on packages tags.
Tests require errata.yaml which should include scenarios
for applying/verifying patches.
Additional variables required by patching tests:
 * PATCHING_MIRRORS - list of repositories with patched
   packages;
 * PATCHING_WEB_DIR - directory on master node which is
   available via HTTP (used for new repository);
 * PATCHING_BUG_ID - bug ID which is going to be fixed;
 * PATCHING_PKGS_TESTS - local path or URL to destination
   where test plans for packages are stored;
 * PATCHING_APPLY_TESTS - local path or URL which should
   be used to get test plans for bugs (using bug ID);
 * PATCHING_PKGS - list of patched packages; if empty -
   list is gotten from test plan (errata.yaml) or from
   repository.

Implements: blueprint mos-patching-tests

Change-Id: Ic696a49bd12504c9e045cf824248ff09bb7d53cb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-qa refs/changes/73/159773/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: PATCHING_PKGS_TOOLS = ['yum-utils', 'dpkg', 'dpkg-devel', 'createrepo'] PATCHING_WEB_DIR = os.environ.get("PATCHING_WEB_DIR", "/var/www/nailgun/") PATCHING_MIRROR = os.environ.get("PATCHING_MIRROR", CUSTOM_PKGS_MIRROR) PATCHING_BUG_ID = os.environ.get("PATCHING_BUG_ID", None) PATCHING_GROUPS = os.environ.get("PATCHING_GROUPS", 'empty_group').split()

commit_message:
Remove modifying dhcrelay for multiple networks

Since Fuel doesn't use dhcrelay anymore remove
its configuring from tests and add info about second
admin interface directly to cobbler/dnsmasq config.

Change-Id: I135baf49506e42515fdb63117b89e9c5bccf9d40
Closes-bug: #1433689

commit_message:
Backport TestRail scripts for 6.0.1

TestRail scripts are needed in stable/6.0
branch in order to upload results of system
tests from CI.

Change-Id: I911021dd262eeefea5ad47906d38a2a3ee1267a0
Closes-bug: #1430747

OptionParser from builds import Build from builds import get_build_artifact from builds import get_downstream_builds_from_html from builds import get_jobs_for_view from launchpad_client import LaunchpadBug from settings import JENKINS from settings import LaunchpadSettings from settings import logger from settings import TestRailSettings from testrail_client import TestRailProject class TestResult(): def __init__(self, name, group, status, duration, url=None, version=None, description=None, launchpad_bug=None): self.name = name self.group = group self._status = status self.duration = duration self.url = url self.version = version self.description = description self.launchpad_bug = launchpad_bug self.available_statuses = { 'passed': ['passed', 'fixed'], 'failed': ['failed', 'regression'], 'skipped': ['skipped'] } @property def status(self): for s in self.available_statuses.keys(): if self._status in self.available_statuses[s]: return s logger.error('Unsupported result status: "{0}"!'.format(self._status)) return self._status @status.setter def status(self, value): self._status = value def __str__(self): result_dict = { 'name': self.name, 'group': self.group, 'status': self.status, 'duration': self.duration, 'url': self.url, 'version': self.version, 'description': self.description } return str(result_dict) def retry(count=3): def wrapped(func): @functools.wraps(func) def wrapper(*args, **kwargs): i = 0 while True: try: return func(*args, **kwargs) except: i += 1 if i >= count: raise return wrapper return wrapped def get_downstream_builds(jenkins_build_data, status=None): if 'subBuilds' not in jenkins_build_data.keys(): return get_downstream_builds_from_html(jenkins_build_data['url']) return [{'name': b['jobName'], 'number': b['buildNumber'], 'result': b['result']} for b in jenkins_build_data['subBuilds']] def get_version(jenkins_build_data): if any([artifact for artifact in jenkins_build_data['artifacts'] if artifact['fileName'] == JENKINS['version_artifact']]): return get_version_from_artifacts(jenkins_build_data, artifact=JENKINS['version_artifact']) else: return get_version_from_magnet_link(jenkins_build_data) def get_version_from_magnet_link(jenkins_build_data): parameters = [a['parameters'] for a in jenkins_build_data['actions'] if 'parameters' in a.keys()][0] iso_link = [p['value'] for p in parameters if p['name'].lower() == 'magnet_link'][0] match = re.search(r'.*\bfuel-(\d+(\.\d+)+)-(\d+)-.*', iso_link) if match: return match.group(1), int(match.group(3)) def get_version_from_artifacts(jenkins_build_data, artifact): version = yaml.load(get_build_artifact( url=jenkins_build_data['url'], artifact=JENKINS['version_artifact'])) return version['VERSION']['release'], \ int(version['VERSION']['build_number']) @retry(count=3) def get_tests_results(systest_build): tests_results = [] test_build = Build(systest_build['name'], systest_build['number']) for test in test_build.test_data()['suites'][0]['cases']: test_result = TestResult( name=test['name'], group=test['className'], status=test['status'].lower(), duration='{0}s'.format(int(test['duration']) + 1), url='{0}testReport/(root)/{1}/'.format(test_build.url, test['name']), version='_'.join([test_build.build_data["id"]] + (test_build.build_data["description"] or test['name']).split()), description=test_build.build_data["description"] or test['name'], ) tests_results.append(test_result) return tests_results def publish_results(project, milestone_id, test_plan, suite_id, config_id, results): test_run_ids = [run['id'] for entry in test_plan['entries'] for run in entry['runs'] if suite_id == run['suite_id'] and config_id in run['config_ids']] logger.debug('Looking for previous tests runs on "{0}" using tests suite ' '"{1}"...'.format(project.get_config(config_id)['name'], project.get_suite(suite_id)['name'])) previous_tests_runs = project.get_previous_runs(milestone_id=milestone_id, suite_id=suite_id, config_id=config_id) cases = project.get_cases(suite_id=suite_id) tests = project.get_tests(run_id=test_run_ids[0]) results_to_publish = [] for result in results: test = project.get_test_by_group(run_id=test_run_ids[0], group=result.group, tests=tests) if not test: logger.error("Test for '{0}' group not found: {1}".format( result.group, result.url)) continue existing_results_versions = [r['version'] for r in project.get_results_for_test(test['id'])] if result.version in existing_results_versions: continue if result.status != 'passed': run_ids = [run['id'] for run in previous_tests_runs[0: int(TestRailSettings.previous_results_depth)]] case_id = project.get_case_by_group(suite_id=suite_id, group=result.group, cases=cases)['id'] previous_results = project.get_all_results_for_case( run_ids=run_ids, case_id=case_id) result.launchpad_bug = get_existing_bug_link(previous_results) results_to_publish.append(result) try: if len(results_to_publish) > 0: project.add_results_for_cases(run_id=test_run_ids[0], suite_id=suite_id, tests_results=results_to_publish) except: logger.error('Failed to add new results for tests: {0}'.format( [r.group for r in results_to_publish] )) raise return results_to_publish @retry(count=3) def get_existing_bug_link(previous_results): results_with_bug = [result for result in previous_results if result["custom_launchpad_bug"] is not None] if not results_with_bug: return for result in sorted(results_with_bug, key=lambda k: k['created_on'], reverse=True): try: bug_id = int(result["custom_launchpad_bug"].strip('/').split( '/')[-1]) except ValueError: logger.warning('Link "{0}" doesn\'t contain bug id.'.format( result["custom_launchpad_bug"])) continue try: bug = LaunchpadBug(bug_id).get_duplicate_of() except KeyError: logger.error("Bug with id '{bug_id}' is private or " "doesn't exist.".format(bug_id=bug_id)) return for target in bug.targets: if target['project'] == LaunchpadSettings.project and\ target['milestone'] == LaunchpadSettings.milestone and\ target['status'] not in LaunchpadSettings.closed_statuses: return result["custom_launchpad_bug"] def main(): parser = OptionParser( description="Publish results of system tests from Jenkins build to " "TestRail. See settings.py for configuration." ) parser.add_option('-j', '--job-name', dest='job_name', default=None, help='Jenkins swarm runner job name') parser.add_option('-N', '--build-number', dest='build_number', default='latest', help='Jenkins swarm runner build number') parser.add_option("-w", "--view", dest="jenkins_view", default=False, help="Get system tests jobs from Jenkins view") parser.add_option("-l", "--live", dest="live_report", action="store_true", help="Get tests results from running swarm") parser.add_option("-m", "--manual", dest="manual_run", action="store_true", help="Manually add tests cases to TestRun (tested only)") parser.add_option("-v", "--verbose", action="store_true", dest="verbose", default=False, help="Enable debug output") (options, args) = parser.parse_args() if options.verbose: logger.setLevel(DEBUG) if options.live_report and options.build_number == 'latest': options.build_number = 'latest_started' # STEP #1 # Initialize TestRail Project and define configuration logger.info('Initializing TestRail Project configuration...') project = TestRailProject(url=TestRailSettings.url, user=TestRailSettings.user, password=TestRailSettings.password, project=TestRailSettings.project) tests_suite = project.get_suite_by_name(TestRailSettings.tests_suite) operation_systems = [{'name': config['name'], 'id': config['id'], 'distro': config['name'].split()[0].lower()} for config in project.get_config_by_name( 'Operation System')['configs'] if config['name'] in TestRailSettings.operation_systems] tests_results = {os['distro']: [] for os in operation_systems} # STEP #2 # Get tests results from Jenkins logger.info('Getting tests results from Jenkins...') if options.jenkins_view: jobs = get_jobs_for_view(options.jenkins_view) tests_jobs = [{'name': j, 'number': 'latest'} for j in jobs if 'system_test' in j] runner_job = [j for j in jobs if 'runner' in j][0] runner_build = Build(runner_job, 'latest') elif options.job_name: runner_build = Build(options.job_name, options.build_number) tests_jobs = get_downstream_builds(runner_build.build_data) else: logger.error("Please specify either Jenkins swarm runner job name (-j)" " or Jenkins view with system tests jobs (-w). Exiting..") return for systest_build in tests_jobs: if options.job_name: if 'result' not in systest_build.keys(): logger.debug("Skipping '{0}' job because it does't run tests " "(build #{1} contains no results)".format( systest_build['name'], systest_build['number'])) continue if systest_build['result'] is None: logger.debug("Skipping '{0}' job (build #{1}) because it's sti" "ll running...".format(systest_build['name'], systest_build['number'],)) continue for os in tests_results.keys(): if os in systest_build['name'].lower(): tests_results[os].extend(get_tests_results(systest_build)) # STEP #3 # Create new TestPlan in TestRail (or get existing) and add TestRuns milestone, iso_number = get_version(runner_build.build_data) milestone = project.get_milestone_by_name(name=milestone) test_plan_name = '{milestone} iso #{iso_number}'.format( milestone=milestone['name'], iso_number=iso_number) test_plan = project.get_plan_by_name(test_plan_name) if not test_plan: test_plan = project.add_plan(test_plan_name, description='/'.join([ JENKINS['url'], 'job', '{0}.all'.format(milestone['name']), str(iso_number)]), milestone_id=milestone['id'], entries=[] ) logger.info('Created new TestPlan "{0}".'.format(test_plan_name)) else: logger.info('Found existing TestPlan "{0}".'.format(test_plan_name)) plan_entries = [] all_cases = project.get_cases(suite_id=tests_suite['id']) for os in operation_systems: cases_ids = [] if options.manual_run: all_results_groups = [r.group for r in tests_results[os['distro']]] for case in all_cases: if case['custom_test_group'] in all_results_groups: cases_ids.append(case['id']) plan_entries.append( project.test_run_struct( name='{suite_name}'.format(suite_name=tests_suite['name']), suite_id=tests_suite['id'], milestone_id=milestone['id'], description='Results of system tests ({tests_suite}) on is' 'o #"{iso_number}"'.format(tests_suite=tests_suite['name'], iso_number=iso_number), config_ids=[os['id']], include_all=True, case_ids=cases_ids ) ) if not any(entry['suite_id'] == tests_suite['id'] for entry in test_plan['entries']): if project.add_plan_entry(plan_id=test_plan['id'], suite_id=tests_suite['id'], config_ids=[os['id'] for os in operation_systems], runs=plan_entries): test_plan = project.get_plan(test_plan['id']) # STEP #4 # Upload tests results to TestRail logger.info('Uploading tests results to TestRail...') for os in operation_systems: logger.info('Checking tests results for "{0}"...'.format(os['name'])) tests_results[os['distro']] = publish_results( project=project, milestone_id=milestone['id'], test_plan=test_plan, suite_id=tests_suite['id'], config_id=os['id'], results=tests_results[os['distro']] ) logger.debug('Added new results for tests ({os}): {tests}'.format( os=os['name'], tests=[r.group for r in tests_results[os['distro']]] )) logger.info('Report URL: {0}'.format(test_plan['url'])) if __name__ == "__main__": main()

commit_message:
Specify time units for default_lock_timeout

Currently, the docstring and sample config entries for
default_lock_timeout do not specify what units of time the value uses
(minutes, seconds, microseconds, etc).  This patch adds units to make
the value easier to understand for operators.

Closes-Bug: #1434620
DocImpact
Change-Id: If6c587e24c13f8ea11725894bfa90a9027e34554

commit_message:
Per-policy DiskFile classes

Adds specific disk file classes for EC policy types.

The new ECDiskFile and ECDiskFileWriter classes are used
by the ECDiskFileManager.

ECDiskFileManager is registered with the DiskFileRouter for
use with EC_POLICY type policies.

Change-Id: I22f915160dc67a9e18f4738c1ddf068344e8ad5d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/25/165125/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from os.path import basename, dirname, exists, getmtime, join, splitext def __init__(self, name, datadir, fd, tmppath, bytes_per_sync, threadpool, diskfile): self._diskfile = diskfile def _make_ondisk_file_name(self, metadata): timestamp = Timestamp(metadata['X-Timestamp']).internal return '%s%s' % (timestamp, self._extension) filename = self._make_ondisk_file_name(metadata) target_path = join(self._datadir, filename)class ECDiskFileWriter(DiskFileWriter): def _make_ondisk_file_name(self, metadata): # TODO: (acoles) the diskfile instance already has frag_index passed # to constructor so why not use that here rather than inspect metadata? fi = metadata.get('X-Object-Sysmeta-Ec-Archive-Index') timestamp = Timestamp(metadata['X-Timestamp']).internal return self._diskfile._mgr.ts_to_fname(timestamp, self._extension, frag_index=fi) def _finalize_durable(self, durable_file_path): exc = msg = None try: with open(durable_file_path, 'w') as _fd: fsync(_fd) try: self.hash_cleanup_listdir(self._datadir) except OSError: logging.exception(_('Problem cleaning up %s'), self._datadir) except OSError: msg = (_('Problem fsyncing durable state file: %s'), durable_file_path) exc = DiskFileError(msg) except IOError as io_err: if io_err.errno in (errno.ENOSPC, errno.EDQUOT): msg = (_("No space left on device for %s"), durable_file_path) exc = DiskFileNoSpace() else: msg = (_('Problem writing durable state file: %s'), durable_file_path) exc = DiskFileError(msg) if exc: logging.exception(msg) raise exc def write_durable_timestamp(self, timestamp): """ Finalize put by writing a timestamp.durable file for the object. We do this for EC policy because it requires a 2-phase put commit confirmation. :param timestamp: object put timestamp """ durable_file_path = join(self._datadir, timestamp + '.durable') self._threadpool.force_run_in_thread( self._finalize_durable, durable_file_path) self._bytes_per_sync, self._threadpool, self)# Uncomment to override legacy DiskFileManager implementation # with ReplicationDiskFileManager #@DiskFileRouter.register(REPL_POLICY) class ReplicationDiskFileManager(DiskFileManager): """ For now this class simply provides a super-class for ECDiskFileManager and could be sucked down into ECDiskFileManager. However, since it provides all the pieces required for a alternative replication policy DiskFileManager implementation, it is pragmatic to have this class separate with a view to it being sucked up into DiskFileManager at some point. """ def fname_to_ts(self, fname, *a, **kw): """ Returns the timestamp extracted from a policy specific .data file name. For replication the timestamp is the filename less extension. :param fname: the data file name including extension :returns: a tuple of (<timestamp>, qualifier) where <timestamp> is a string representing the timestamp extracted from the file name and <qualifier> is any policy-specific qualifying string found in the filename. <qualifier> may be None. """ return splitext(fname)[0], '' def is_obsolete(self, filename, other_filename): """ Test if a given file is considered to be obsolete with respect to another file in an object storage dir. The default behavior is to simply compare the two filenames. However, a policy may override this method to implement a different policy-specific behavior. :param filename: a string representing an absolute filename :param other_filename: a string representing an absolute filename :returns: True if filename is considered obsolete and should therefore be deleted; False otherwise. """ return filename < other_filename def _gather_on_disk_file(self, filename, ext, accepted_files, **kwargs): """ Called by diskfile.get_ondisk_files() for each file in an object datadir in reverse sorted order. This method should accept on disk files by adding them to the accepted files dict. When the search is deemed complete, and True is returned, the gathered files will satisfy one of two conditions: * ts_file is not None and data_file is None and meta_file is None and durable_file is None object is considered deleted * (data_file is not None or durable_file is not None) and ts_file is None object exists, and optionally has fast-POST metadata :param filename: name of file to be accepted or not :param ext: extension part of filename :param accepted_files: dict of files that have been previously accepted by a call to this method, keyed by filename extension, and the file considered to define the newest valid data timestamp, keyed by 'newest' :returns: True if all wanted files have been found, False otherwise """ if ext == '.ts': accepted_files.setdefault('newest', filename) accepted_files['.meta'] = None done = True elif ext == '.data': accepted_files.setdefault('newest', filename) done = True else: done = False # gather the first of each file extension accepted_files.setdefault(ext, filename) == filename return done def _verify_on_disk_files(self, accepted_files, **kwargs): """ Verify that the final combination of on disk files complies with the diskfile contract. :param accepted_files: files that have been found and accepted :returns: True if the file combination is compliant, False otherwise """ data_file, meta_file, ts_file = tuple( [accepted_files.get(ext) for ext in ('.data', '.meta', '.ts')]) return ((data_file is None and meta_file is None and ts_file is None) or (ts_file is not None and data_file is None and meta_file is None) or (data_file is not None and ts_file is None)) def gather_ondisk_files(self, files, **kwargs): """ Given a simple list of files names, determine the files to use. :params files: simple set of files as a python list :params datadir: directory name files are from for convenience :params frag_index: EC may have multiple fragment index data files so if specified this identifies the desired one :returns: a tuple of data, meta, tombstone and durable. """ files.sort(reverse=True) accepted_files = {} for afile in files: ts_file = accepted_files.get('.ts') data_file = accepted_files.get('.data') assert ts_file is None, "On-disk file search loop" \ " continuing after tombstone, %s, encountered" % ts_file assert data_file is None, "On-disk file search loop" \ " continuing after data file, %s, encountered" % data_file ext = splitext(afile)[1] if self._gather_on_disk_file(afile, ext, accepted_files, **kwargs): break assert self._verify_on_disk_files(accepted_files, **kwargs), \ "On-disk file search algorithm contract is broken: %s" \ % accepted_files.values() return accepted_files def get_ondisk_files(self, files, datadir, **kwargs): """ Given a simple list of files names, determine the files to use. :params files: simple set of files as a python list :params datadir: directory name files are from for convenience :params frag_index: EC may have multiple fragment index data files so if specified this identifies the desired one :returns: a tuple of data, meta, tombstone and durable. """ # maintain compatibility with 'legacy' get_ondisk_files return value accepted_files = self.gather_ondisk_files(files, **kwargs) result = [(join(datadir, accepted_files.get(ext)) if accepted_files.get(ext) else None) for ext in ('.data', '.meta', '.ts')] return tuple(result) def hash_cleanup_listdir(self, hsh_path, reclaim_age=ONE_WEEK): """ List contents of a hash directory and clean up any old files: - For replication policy, delete files older than a .data or .ts file - For EC policy, delete files older than a .durable or .ts file :param hsh_path: object hash path :param reclaim_age: age in seconds at which to remove tombstones :returns: list of files remaining in the directory, reverse sorted """ files = listdir(hsh_path) if len(files) == 1: if files[0].endswith('.ts'): # remove tombstones older than reclaim_age ts = files[0].rsplit('.', 1)[0] if (time.time() - float(Timestamp(ts))) > reclaim_age: remove_file(join(hsh_path, files[0])) files.remove(files[0]) elif files: files.sort(reverse=True) accepted_files = self.gather_ondisk_files(files) newest_file = accepted_files.get('newest') meta_file = accepted_files.get('.meta') if newest_file: for filename in list(files): if (self.is_obsolete(filename, newest_file) or (meta_file and filename.endswith('.meta') and filename < meta_file)): remove_file(join(hsh_path, filename)) files.remove(filename) return files class ECDiskFile(DiskFile): writer_cls = ECDiskFileWriter def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super(ECDiskFile, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) frag_index = kwargs.get('frag_index') self._frag_index = int(frag_index) if frag_index is not None else None def get_ondisk_files(self, files, datadir, **kwargs): return self._mgr.get_ondisk_files( files, datadir, frag_index=self._frag_index, **kwargs) class ECDiskFileManager(ReplicationDiskFileManager): diskfile_cls = ECDiskFile def ts_to_fname(self, timestamp, ext=None, *a, **kw): fragment_index = kw.get('frag_index') rv = timestamp if fragment_index not in (None, ''): # we encode the fragment index in the filename to allow # archives of different indexes to temporarily be stored # on the same node in certain situations rv += '#' + str(fragment_index) if ext: rv = '%s%s' % (rv, ext) return rv def fname_to_ts(self, fname, *a, **kw): """ For EC policy the data file name includes a fragment index which must be stripped off to retrieve the timestamp. """ fi = None timestamp = splitext(fname)[0] if '#' in timestamp: timestamp, fi = timestamp.split('#', 1) return timestamp, fi def is_obsolete(self, filename, other_filename): """ Overrides super-class method to implement EC policy specific behavior when comparing files against a .durable file. The default implementation would consider t2#1.data to be older than t2.durable (since t2#1.data < t2.durable). By stripping off the file extensions we get the desired behavior: t2#1 > t2 without compromising the detection of t1#1 < t2. """ if other_filename.endswith('.durable'): return splitext(filename)[0] < splitext(other_filename)[0] return filename < other_filename def _gather_on_disk_file(self, filename, ext, accepted_files, **kwargs): """ In addition to the conditions imposed by the default gather method, for EC policy when the search is deemed complete, and True is returned, the gathered files will satisfy one of two conditions: * data_file is None or durable_file is not None * if data_file then data_file timestamp == durable_file timestamp """ frag_index = kwargs.get('frag_index') done = False if accepted_files.get('.durable'): if ext in ('.durable', '.meta'): # there can no longer be a matching .data file done = True if ext == '.data': if self.is_obsolete(filename, accepted_files.get('.durable')): # this and remaining data files are older than durable done = True else: t_data, fi = self.fname_to_ts(filename) if frag_index is None or frag_index == int(fi): done = True accepted_files.setdefault(ext, filename) # else: for EC we keep searching first for a .data file # that matches the specific frag_index requested elif ext == '.data': # ignore .data found before any .durable elif ext == '.durable': accepted_files.setdefault('newest', filename) accepted_files.setdefault(ext, filename) else: dflt_gather = super(ECDiskFileManager, self)._gather_on_disk_file done = dflt_gather(filename, ext, accepted_files, **kwargs) return done def _verify_on_disk_files(self, accepted_files, **kwargs): frag_index = kwargs.get('frag_index') if frag_index is not None and not accepted_files.get('.data'): # We may find only a .meta if searching for a specific frag index # that is not present. That does not mean the on disk contract is # broken, so clear the .meta to comply with superclass assertions. accepted_files['.meta'] = None data_file, meta_file, ts_file, durable_file = tuple( [accepted_files.get(ext) for ext in ('.data', '.meta', '.ts', '.durable')]) return ((data_file is None or durable_file is not None) and (data_file is None and meta_file is None and ts_file is None and durable_file is None) or (ts_file is not None and data_file is None and meta_file is None and durable_file is None) or (data_file is not None and durable_file is not None and ts_file is None) or (durable_file is not None and meta_file is None and ts_file is None))

commit_message:
Test swift-object-info opens meta and ts files

Adds a unit test to verify the change made in [1], i.e. that
swift-object-info will read from .meta and .ts files as well
as .data files.

[1] change I43966d371218ad39414e9282cde579e48370a2a7

Change-Id: I82dde36e3a96db1a21cfe9a4cca0d941e543dfd0

commit_message:
Fixing tasks operations in mistralclient

 * Deleted PUT/update operation from lib and CLI
 * Recovered filtering tasks by workflow execution:
   mistral task-list [workflow-execution-id]

Partially implements blueprint mistral-refactor-task-output

Change-Id: I0bf975f874865bbd178120cb3f1062812f3351ac
